answers.answer: Kick your gp to the curb and find an endocrinologist that specializes in thyroid problems. You DO NEED ONE!  That's the problem with most gp's - they have no right to tell you that.Get to an endo as soon as you can.You said your thyroid level was 300 - was that your tsh?  do you have copies of your tests?  If so, post them  here - we can all help you interpret them.Peace,Charley

I'm guessing your level you are referring to is your TSH level?!?!  If so, wow!  I only hit somewhere around 80 and I couldn't function - I have no idea how you are managing at 300.Charlie1986 has good advice - kick your GP and get a good endocrinologist who specializes in thyroids (many only treat diabetes) ASAP!!!  No doctor has the right to refuse you the care you NEED and you NEED an endocrinologist!If the level you are talking about is your TSH you are very (VERY!!) hypo,  Here is a bit of information that may help you:http://www.cumc.columbia.edu/dept/thyroid/http://www.endocrineweb.com/hypo1.htmlPlease find a good endo and keep us posted!
Please see an endo ASAP.  Thyroid problems are complex and requiere someone specialized.

Thanks guys for your advice!!! Should I DEMAND to see an Endo?? Cause my insurance requires my pc to refer me.  And she says no...And she is also saying  "I just dont know what to do!" Ugh this is crazy..They've done every test in the book for the high blood pressure and other symptoms..finding NOTHING...and she even sent me to a cardiologist but shes refusing to send me to the Endo..hmmm...Nobody and i mean nobody seems to understand hypothyroidism ...Im just so glad to find this forummmmmm!!!!!I couldnt function AT ALL when my ths was at 300 and I feel so much better now atthe level of 62.i cant imagine what normal is...Will I ever feel normal? And will i ever be able to lose this 60 lbs ive added on in one year????

Yes, DEMAND to see an endo.   You can start nicer but don't let your doctor off the hook without a referral.  If worse comes to worse call your insurance company and talk to a patient advocate.  Hypothyroidism is dangerous and can cause permanent damage to your body and/or death.Having your thyroid levels so far off for such a long time not only causes you to gain weight, become depressed, and feel awful - it also puts you at an increased risk of diabetes and heart problems!http://www.thyroid.ca/Articles/EngE6A.htmlhttp://journal.diabetes.org/clinicaldiabetes/v18n12000/Pg38.htmI'm sure that if you explain to your insurance company how they will be SAVING money by sending you to an endocrinologist instead of treating your for a heart condition or diabetes, they might just see the light.  :-)
I can't even imagine!  I read on here somewhere that the level can go as high as 600 before it's off the chart.Hope you get your TSH level down quick!  Best wishes!

yes...i can beat that....in 93 when i was first diagnosed my tsh was 485 and it took slow increases of over a years time to bring it down to a normal range....and no i dont think that an endo is any more competent of treating thyroid disease than a gp or fp...the ones i had met w/for my daughter were less knowledgeable than the dr i am working w/now.(or less willing to work with you to fix the problem). i think if you find a doc who is willing to work w/you and get you better and not bandaid everything with another drug is more beneficial.

My daughter (6 years old) was just diagnosed with hypothyroidism. The doctor said her TSH levels were 300. I'm trying to understand all of this. He said, levels that high are rare yet, he simply put her on thyroxin .05mcg. Should we be treating this more aggressively?

I don't know the answer .. you may want to try posting on the Dr./Patient forum .. Dr. Lupo is great ...  This thread was started back in Jan '07 (just as I was recovering from my surgery LOL) so not sure if many will see the response, etc.Dr. Lupo:http://www.medhelp.org/forums/show/120Cheryl

I believe when I first was diagnosed my tsh was 980 -  extremely high.  When I went to the ER my blood pressure was over 200/125 or something like that.  They told me not to worry about the blood pressure as it was thyroid induced. That was 8-9 months after I had the RAI and wasn't on any medicine at all.  Once they put me on the medicine it came down and is not at 5.6 still not normal but getting there.  I think absolutely go to an endo that specializes in thyroid, not diabetes.  You will find them in all of the good hospitals.  Praying for you and Merry Christmas.   linda

question: I was admitted to the hospital for dangerously high blood pressure about a year ago. My blood pressure was at 225/128. While they were trying to lower my blood pressure they also discovered from labs taken that my thyroid level was at 300!!!Since then every six weeks my level of levothyroxin has been increased, currently at 225 mcg and they are still going to increase it..my thyroid level was at 57 last month and has now INCREASED...yes increased to 62 this month...I have had all kinds of tests done for all the other symptoms..i requested that i be referred to an endocrinologist, but my primary care dr. says I dont need one. My blood pressure has now been diagnosed as malignant high blood pressure...meaning it wont go down under 160/100 .Ive gained about 45lbs in the last 9 months and I am not losing any even after exercise and diet..My heart is fine and so are my kidneys. I feel swelling in my glands in my neck, Is this a sign of something? I feel ignorant about this disease!!!! Someone please give me some advice.  Thanks
